msContents.textLang: Anglo-Norman, Middle English [Ely/West Norfolk dialect] and Latin

msItem.title: Verse prologue to the Lettre d'Hippocrate]
msItem.rubric: 1r Hic incipit liber yocrasii galieni et sclepei
msItem.incipit: 1r Ypocras se liuere fyt / Ale emperour cesar myt / Demandant si vol[e]z viuere / Entendez ben a moun liuere
msItem.explicit: 1r Voit humme lez jugemens / De mettrez e de sage gens
msItem.note: The text features English glosses and recipes in Latin and Anglo-Norman.

msItem.title: Uroscopic treatise and recipes
msItem.textLang: Latin with a few Middle English plant names
msItem.incipit: 1r Vrina viri laui est pura et aurei coloris

msItem.title: Uroscopic treatise from the Lettre d'Hippocrate
msItem.textLang: Anglo-Norman text with a Latin heading
msItem.incipit: 2r Si le urine seyt blanche de tut le matyn e ruge aprés manger, signifiet sainté
msItem.explicit: 3r E pu[r] ce ky hummez sunt de diverse humurez e de qualitez, encountre checun qualité plusurs averés medicinez, a comenssement a cheif e pus a tous autrez menbres

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes (recipe section of the Lettre d'Hippocrate)
msItem.incipit: 3r Pur le chef. Pernés .ii. unces de betoyne e .iii. unces de here te[re]stre þat is heyhowe e .viii. unces de puliole þat ys hulwrt e les fettis brayer en une morter
msItem.explicit: 35r-35v For boystynge. Item de fleobotomia in tempore idonio facta mentem sincerat vesicam purificat serebrum temperet medullum [...] depellit angustiam bonum sanguinem alit et malum destruit et longiorem lucem in vita tua tenet
msItem.note: This collection of c. 225 medical recipes, Hunt's 'First Corpus Compendium', contains groups of recipes that Hunt (2001) categories as recipes for the head, ears, eyes, mouth, throat, teeth, facial blemishes, staunching blood, limbs, and against poisons. The collection contains charms (see below) and prognostic texts that will tell whether a patient will be cured. These instructions involve a drink with the herb mushere (f. 29r); a drink with the herb pimpernel (f. 31r); a drink with lettuce (f. 31r); a hen's egg laid on the first day of the patient's sickness that needs to be inscribed with magical characters (f. 34v); and bread or lard that needs to rubbed on the patient's chest and subsequently given to dogs (f. 34v).

msItem.title: Charm for eye ailments involving an amulet invoking the Trinity for help
Charm for staunching blood with magical names that need to be written on the patient's forehead with their own blood
Charm for staunching blood by invoking the Virgin Mary and Christ
Charm for staunching blood invoking the River Jordan (variant of the Flum Jordan charm)
Charm for indigestion requiring a cross to be made on the patient with an ointment of grain
Charm for staunching blood in a woman with magical characters
Charm for staunching blood invoking Christ's baptism in the River Jordan
Charms for ulcers invoking the story of the tres boni fratres on the Mount of Olives
Charm for wounds that invokes the bodies of the Virgin Mary and Christ
Charm for wounds using a lead plate with crosses (attributed to Ypocras)
Charm for wounds with a lead plate with crosses
Charm for Falling Evil invoking the Three Magi
Charm for Falling Evil involving an amulet with magical words
Charm for staunching blood with magical names that need to be written on the patient's forehead with their own blood
Health recommendations
msItem.incipit: 35r Item qui curabilis est dura et acetosa vitet carnes procinas, dulcia poma cocta, et mel comedat et magnos labores non faciat
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Hunt (2001), p. 151.

msItem.title: Note on bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 35r Item cave ne minuas ultra modum et oram vir[um] vel mulier[em] quia quisque minuit sibi sanguinem ultra mensuram isti morbi inde venient: Interiora efficit frigida et facit deesse calorem et morbus glaucus inde pervenit et debilitat cerebrum et facit manus tremere gutteque multe inde veniunt et inde venit tussis cordis et morbus capitis et multa alia mala inde emergunt
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Hunt (2001), p. 152.

msItem.title: Health regimen by months
msItem.author: Pseudo-Galen
msItem.incipit: 35v Item hic docet gallilenus medicus tempora comestionum et potacionum et sanguinis municionum. In mense ianuarii ieiunio stomaco album vinum est bonum potare
msItem.explicit: 35v Item in mense octobri mustum est bonum ad potandum
msItem.note: The text ends abruptly due to the loss of the next folio. As Tavormina (2019), p. xxxiv notes, this is a Latin equivalent to the text in Linne R. Mooney, 'Diet and Bloodletting: A Monthly Regimen', in Practical and Popular Science of Medieval England, ed. by Lister M. Matheson (East Lansing, MI: Colleagues Press, 1994), pp. 245-262.

msItem.title: List of contents for the Second Corpus Compendium
msItem.incipit: 36r For werk of hefed

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes (Second Corpus Compendium)
msItem.textLang: Middle English with a few phrases in Latin and one recipe in Anglo-Norman
msItem.rubric: 36r Here bygennes mani a god medecine þat leches han drawn out of þe bokes of Galion and Sclepius and Ypocras
msItem.incipit: 36r For werk [and] turning braynus. Quo so haues werk and turning in his hed mack leye of verueyne or of betoyne or of filles or of wirmod and þarwit wasse þin hed þries in þe woke
msItem.explicit: 48v And quan it is cold tempur ful a saucer of þat water wit als mychel of eld ale mad of barly malt and drinck it
msItem.finalRubric: 48v Expliciunt medicine de tractatibus Ypocracii, Gallieni et Sclepeii etcaetera
msItem.note: This collection of c. 185 medical recipes, Hunt's 'Second Corpus Compendium', features many different categories of recipes. Unlike the previous collection, this one does not contain any charms but it does feature three prognostic texts for determining whether patients will be cured or not on f. 48r. These texts involve analysis of the patient's physical features as well as treatment of their urine with breast milk.
This is the earliest known version of the Liber de Diversis Medicinis.

msItem.title: Recipe for a medical ointment against a fistula
msItem.incipit: 48v Item vngwentum ad fistulam accipe de radice altee et centauria et edera terestri equaliter
msItem.explicit: 48v et a lacte a coitij se abstineat

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating chest pain
msItem.incipit: 48v Item ad infirmitatem pecurum [sic] tolle corticem ?quartimum et fac cinerem inde postea ?lescinam quam des pecori bibere et ieiunet ?qualenicum habuit et sanabitur sine dubio

msItem.title: Recipe to make a dark horse white
msItem.textLang: Latin recipe with a Middle English heading
msItem.incipit: 48v Item for to maken a black hors qwyt accipe talpam et pone in aqua et dimitte eam stare in ea .iiij.or diebus et post ea
msItem.note: Full transcription. The text ends abruptly due to the loss of the next folio.

msItem.title: Glossary of the names of herbs and trees (Latin-English)
msItem.incipit: 49r Millefolium anglice Milefolye
msItem.note: The text probably begins imperfectly as other items from the glossare were probably contained on the preceding (missing) leaf.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes for treating haemorrhoids
msItem.incipit: 49r tack muleyn and wellit in sqwet mylck and ley it hoyt to þe sor
msItem.explicit: 49r Or take herbe benet and spires of þe redde docke onyounes and galt smere and stamp alle to gedere and ley on þe sore

msItem.title: Glossary of the names of herbs and trees (Latin-English)
msItem.incipit: 49r Atramentum id est incaustum

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating constipation
msItem.incipit: 49r Cene bonum ad potandum pro scilicet costiuesoun . portat siliqueras ad modum pisarum

msItem.title: Poem on bloodletting in relation to the twelve signs of the Zodiac from the Regimen sanitatis Salernitanum
msItem.incipit: 49v Nil capiti facies aries dum luna refulget - Aries
msItem.explicit: 49v Carpe viam tutus sit pocio supra salubris - Pissis

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 50r Item contra cancrum in virga virili
msItem.explicit: 50v cum aqua calida et albumine oui reddit faciem et manus albas et molles et suaues

msItem.title: 'Secret Medicine'
msItem.author: 'H. Sampsonis de Clouburnel'
msItem.rubric: 50v Secreta medicine H. Sampsonis de Clouburnel
msItem.incipit: 50v Seus sunt lez erbes quy sunt appele lez .v. launces quy menoit a le playe
msItem.note: The location Clouburnel refers to Clos Bruneau, Paris [see Tavormina (2019), p. xxxiv].

msItem.title: Medical recipe for joint pain
msItem.incipit: 51r Item \a/ gute epo dolour en les iount[o]us

msItem.title: Charm for healing that St Gabriel brought to Susanna
msItem.rubric: 51r Ce est le charme seynt gabriel le portat par nostre seygnour pur charmer crestienes de verm . de gute . de kancie . de festre . de gute rauncle . de gute en ossee . e de tut manere de gute prime ueriment faites chaunter vn messe del seynte Espirite e pus dites sette charme
msItem.incipit: 51r In nomine patris et

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: The collection ends with an Anglo-Norman charm (with Latin formula) to aid pregnant women in childbirth and another one for women to (?) become pregnant.

msItem.title: On the names and virtues of herbs
msItem.textLang: Latin with some Middle English plant names
msItem.incipit: 52r Gariofila latine Romanice gariofle anglice erbe mauen

msItem.title: Urine White and Brown
msItem.rubric: 53v Her mayst þou knowen vrines be coloures
msItem.incipit: 53v Vrine qwyt at morwen and brown after mete þat is signe of god hele
msItem.explicit: 54r Vrine qwit and broun abouen signe of werl[e]z in þe leindes [sic] and þat þe matrice is ful of wateres and of wicke humores of cold
msItem.note: As Tavormina (2019), p. xxxv notes, this is the earliest version of a Middle English uroscopic text.

msItem.title: Latin verse
msItem.incipit: 54r Omnibus est notum quod multum diligo
msItem.note: Full transcription; unfinished version of the verse: Omnibus est notum quod multum diligo potum (for this verse, see Joanna Bellis and Venetia Bridges, '"What shalt thou do when thou hast an english to make into Latin?" The Proverb Collection of Cambridge, St John's College, MS F.26', Studies in Philology, 112:1 (2015), 68-92 (p. 75 fn. 26) [without this manuscript]). Added by a (?) late 14th-century or 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Erased inscription
msItem.incipit: 54v ffalls [? ffalis] [...]yng
msItem.note: Added in the (?) 15th century. The inscription has either been erased or damaged from having been glued onto the inside of the rear cover of the previous binding. It may be an owner's name, referring to a member of the Falls family, but the inscription could be something else as well. Tavormina (2019), p. xxxv reads ffa??S fflemyng.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
f. 35a is a triangular remnant of a leaf, incorporated into a longer stub formed of modern parchment.

list.item: Quire 56-3 (ff. 33-35a verso: 4th, 5th and 6th leaves missing; only a small portion remains of the 6th leaf)
Quire 78-2 (ff. 44-49: 6th and 7th leaves missing, after f. 48)
Quire 86-2+1 (ff. 50-54: 1st and 2nd leaves missing; 1 leaf inserted at the end, f. 54)

p.formula: 1-48 56-3 (3rd, 5th and 6th missing) 68 78-2 (6th-7th missing) 86-2+1 (1st-2nd missing; 1 added after 6th)

signatures.p: Roman numerals in red ink in the upper margins of the first halves of quires, but mostly cropped off.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the right-hand lower corners of the last versos of quires.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Double columns. 40 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-48v, 49r (upper left and right columns), 49v have been copied by a single scribe in an informal Gothic textura script.
Folios 49v (lower left column), 52r-54r have been copied by a (?) single scribe, perhaps the same scribe who copied ff. 1r-49v, in a script that can be identified as Anglicana.
Folios 50r-52r have been copied by a single hand, perhaps the same hand that copied ff. 1r-49v, in an informal Gothic textura script.

decoNote.p: Large (2-line) initials in blue with penwork decoration and pen-flourishing in red ink.
One-line capitals higlighted in red ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.
Long decorative ascenders on the top lines highlighted in red ink, but not the long decorative descenders on the lower lines.

binding.p: 20th-century white leather over wooden boards with the spine on 8 raised bands; the manuscript was disbound and restored in 1996 with a grant from SmithKline Beecham (according to a paper label pasted on the inside of the upper cover) by the book conservator Nicholas Hadgraft (1955-2004) as stated on a paper label on theinside of the rear cover.

The manuscript's previous binding is kept separately and concerns a (?) 17th-century half brown leather binding with white vellum over pasterboards. Inside the old binding are three unfoliated modern paper flyleaves, the first of which bears the College's stamp and is inscribed with the classmark: MS 388.

On the front cover of the old binding is a cropped (?) 17th-century inscription: Wardall his. This may be a title written on the reverse of an older legal document from Corpus Christi College with the text of that document pasted onto the outsides of the front and rear covers. (For example, a John Wardall of Cambridge, brewer, features in a copy of a bond to the Master and Fellows of Cambridge, Corpus Christi College dated 1485 [Cambridge, University Archives, GBR/0268/CCCC09/06/1Ka]; but members of the Wardall family also feature in 16th-century legal documents from Corpus Christi College).

provenance.p: Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury: the manuscript is recorded as Medicinis in olde Englishe among the Libri in minore Bibliotheca on f. 61r of his register of books, now Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 575 [see M.R. James (1912), I, p. xxxvi].

acquisition.p: Presented to Corpus Christi College by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575: The number 388 inscribed in pencil on f. 1r. Listed as no. 161 in Thomas James's Ecloga Oxonio-Catabrigiensis, printed in London in 1600; no. R.8 in William Stanley, Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum in Bibliotheca Collegiis Corporis Christi in Cantabrigia: Quos legauit Matthaeus Parkerus Archiepiscopus Cantuariensis, printed in London in 1722 (see also the inscription R.8 on f. ii recto); and no. 388 in James Nasmith, Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum quos Collegio Corporis Christi et B. Mariae Virginis in Academia Cantabrigiensis legauit Reverendissimus in Christo Pater Matthaeus Parker, Archiepiscopus Cantuariensis printed in Cambridge in 1777.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, 2 vols (Cambridge, 1912), no. 388; and Kari Anne Rand, Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XX (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), pp. 101-116. Images and a description of the manuscript are also available on the Parker Library website: the online catalogue entry for the item published at Parker on the Web Corpus Christi College, MS 388.

availability.p: Visitors to Corpus Christi College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Parker Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Parker Library: Information for Readers.

listBibl.bibl: For a bibliography for this item maintained by Corpus Christi College Cambridge see: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 388: Zotero Bibliography
